Introduction

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a condition in which thickening and elongation of the pylorus causes gastric outlet obstruction, leading to nonbilious projectile emesis at age 3-6 weeks.

Pathophysiology



Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis results from hypertrophy of the circular layer of smooth muscle that surrounds the pylorus (

figure 1
).  The hypertrophic smooth muscle impedes the passage of gastric contents, causing gastric outlet obstruction and nonbilious projectile emesis.  The etiology of this abnormal postnatal growth of smooth muscle is likely multifactorial, involving the interplay of genetic predisposition with environmental exposures.

Risk factors



  • Firstborn status
  • Male sex
  • Family history of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
  • Macrolide antibiotic (eg, erythromycin) exposure (likely related to smooth muscle hypertrophy due to motilin receptor stimulation)
  • Bottle-feeding
  • Maternal smoking during pregnancy

Clinical presentation



Patients with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis typically develop symptoms at age 3-6 weeks (rarely after age 12 weeks), with the following findings:



  • Nonbilious projectile emesis that occurs immediately after feeding
  • Eager to refeed soon after emesis ("hungry vomiter")


Physical examination is often normal, but classic findings include the following:



  • A palpable olive-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen is due to the hypertrophied muscle.  When present, the "olive" is pathognomonic of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.
  • Peristaltic waves may be visible as muscle contractions attempt to move gastric contents beyond the obstruction.


In addition, there may be signs of weight loss and dehydration (eg, sunken fontanelle, dry mucous membranes, decreased urine output), particularly if diagnosis is delayed.

Diagnosis



For patients with suspected pyloric stenosis, the preferred imaging modality is abdominal ultrasonography because visualization of the thickened, elongated pyloric muscle confirms the diagnosis (

image 1
).



Although laboratory results may be initially normal in patients with recent onset of symptoms, they are useful in assessing dehydration and electrolyte disturbances related to persistent vomiting (classically hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis) (

figure 2
).



Persistent vomiting causes significant gastric hydrochloric acid loss, which leads to metabolic alkalosis.  Hypochloremia occurs because there is a relatively greater loss of chloride than sodium from the stomach.  Persistent vomiting also causes significant fluid loss, which leads to decreased renal perfusion and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) (

figure 3
).  The RAAS causes increased bicarbonate reabsorption and hydrogen ion excretion, further contributing to metabolic alkalosis.  Aldosterone also causes potassium excretion in the collecting duct, resulting in hypokalemia.



Persistent dehydration also stimulates the appropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone in an attempt to restore euvolemia, which leads to free water retention and, in severe cases, hyponatremia.  Dehydration also increases enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin, leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which may be seen in some patients.

Differential diagnosis



  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD):  is characterized in infants by regurgitation of gastric contents into the esophagus that leads to poor weight gain, feeding refusal, and irritability.  In contrast to pyloric stenosis, GERD is characterized by nonprojectile emesis with variable frequency after feeds.  In addition, although abdominal examination is typically normal (as with early pyloric stenosis), signs of dehydration are not seen in reflux and immediate refeeding attempts are less common.
  • Malrotation (with or without volvulus) (
    figure 4
    ):  leads to intestinal obstruction with abdominal distension, high-pitched bowel sounds, and bilious emesis, in contrast to the nonbilious emesis seen in pyloric stenosis.
  • Food proteinâ€“induced allergic proctocolitis:  typically presents with normal or loose stools with blood and mucus due to a nonâ€“IgE-mediated inflammatory response to food proteins, most commonly cow's milk, in early infancy.  Unlike pyloric stenosis, emesis is uncommon because the inflammatory response is limited to the distal sigmoid colon and rectum.

Management



Management of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is with pyloromyotomy, a surgical procedure involving longitudinal incision of the hypertrophic pyloric muscle.  Patients with dehydration or electrolyte derangements should first receive intravenous hydration and electrolyte repletion to decrease the risk for postoperative apnea and to improve their overall outcome.

Prognosis



The prognosis for infants with pyloric stenosis is excellent following surgical intervention.  Complications are rare, and the majority of patients resume normal feeding patterns within hours of the operation.

Summary



Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (
